facts.text: This is Criminal Appeal No. 165 of 1957 in the Supreme Court.

anchor.surface_text: CRIMINAL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Criminal Appeal No. 165 of 1957.

facts.text: Appeal is by special leave from the judgment and order dated 4th August 1955 of Patna High Court.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal by special leave from the judgment and order dated the 4th August, 1955, of the Patna High Court in Criminal Appeal No. 699 of 1953 with Criminal

facts.text: Patna High Court case arose from Criminal Appeal No. 699 of 1953 with Criminal Revision No. 205 of 1954.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal No. 699 of 1953 with Criminal Revision No. 205 of 1954, arising out of the judgment and order dated the 12th December, 1953, of the Court of the

facts.text: Trial was before Assistant Sessions Judge, Second Court Chapra in Trial No. 70 of 1953.

anchor.surface_text: arising out of the judgment and order dated the 12th December, 1953, of the Court of the Assistant Sessions Judge, Second Court Chapra in Trial No. 70 of 1953.

facts.text: Assistant Sessions Judge delivered judgment and order dated 12th December 1953.

anchor.surface_text: judgment and order dated the 12th December, 1953, of the Court of the Assistant Sessions Judge

facts.text: Appellants along with others tried before Assistant Sessions Judge of Chapra for offence of dacoity under s.395 IPC.

anchor.surface_text: The appellants, along with others, were placed on their trial before the Assistant Sessions Judge of Chapra in the district of Saran, for the offence of dacoity under s. 395, Indian Penal Code.

facts.text: Appellants along with two others convicted under s.395 IPC and sentenced to 5 years rigorous imprisonment by Assistant Sessions Judge on December 12, 1953.

anchor.surface_text: They, along with two others, were convicted under s. 395, Indian Penal Code, and sentenced to rigorous imprisonment for 5 years, by the Assistant Sessions Judge, by his Judgment and order dated December 12, 1953.

facts.text: Other accused were acquitted by Assistant Sessions Judge.

anchor.surface_text: The other accused were acquitted.

facts.text: Convicted persons appealed to Patna High Court.

anchor.surface_text: The convicted persons preferred an appeal to the High Court at Patna.

facts.text: High Court while admitting appeal called upon appellants to show cause why sentence should not be enhanced if convictions maintained.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court, in its revisional jurisdiction, while admitting the appeal, called upon the appellants to show cause why, in the event of their convictions being maintained, their sentence should not be enhanced.

facts.text: Appeal and rule for enhancement heard together by Division Bench of Patna High Court.

anchor.surface_text: The appeal and the rule for enhancement of sentence were heard together by a Division Bench of that Court.

facts.text: Patna High Court by judgment dated August 4, 1955 allowed appeal of two appellants and acquitted them.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court, by its judgment and order dated August 4, 1955, allowed the appeal of two of the appellants and acquitted them

facts.text: Patna High Court maintained conviction of remaining six appellants.

anchor.surface_text: but maintained the conviction as against the remaining six appellants.

facts.text: Patna High Court enhanced sentence to 10 years rigorous imprisonment for the six appellants.

anchor.surface_text: It, therefore, enhanced the sentence to 10 years rigorous imprisonment in each and obtained special leave to appeal limited to the question of sentence only,

facts.text: Supreme Court granted special leave to appeal limited to question of sentence.

anchor.surface_text: obtained special leave to appeal limited to the question of sentence only, the question being whether the High Court had the jurisdiction to enhance

facts.text: Dacoity occurred on the night between July 1 and 2, 1952 in the house of Ranjit Bahadur, a minor.

anchor.surface_text: The occurrence of dacoity which is the subjectmatter of the charge against the appellants, along with others, took place on the night between July 1 and 2, 1952, in the house of Ranjit Bahadur, a minor.

facts.text: 16 or 17 dacoits fully armed with deadly weapons broke open main entrance door with axe after midnight.

anchor.surface_text: After midnight, 16 or 17 dacoits, fully armed with various deadly weapons, broke open the main entrance door of the house with an axe.

facts.text: Dacoits broke open boxes and tampered with iron safe, removed articles worth twenty thousand rupees.

anchor.surface_text: After going into the house, they broke open boxes and tampered with the iron safe, and removed articles worth twenty thousand rupees.

facts.text: Inmates of the house were over-powered by dacoits.

anchor.surface_text: The inmates of the house were over-powered.

facts.text: Some inmates raised alarm by big fire, villagers turned up but did not face dacoits for fear, used brickbats.

anchor.surface_text: Some of them, slipping out of the house, raised a big fire which is the customary form of alarm raised against the invading crowd of dacoits. On that alarm, a number of people of the village turned up but had not the courage to face the dacoits for fear of being shot. They contented themselves with using brickbats against the dacoits

facts.text: Dacoits escaped with booty.

anchor.surface_text: who made good their escape with their booty.

facts.text: Assistant Sessions Judge could not impose more than 7 years imprisonment.

anchor.surface_text: The learned trial judge could not have imposed a term of imprisonment exceeding 7 years.

facts.text: High Court judgment delivered on October 28, 1957.

anchor.surface_text: 1957. October 28. The following judgment of the Court was delivered by SINHA J.-

facts.text: High Court enhanced sentence from 5 to 10 years RI considering dacoity heinous and inadequate sentence.

anchor.surface_text: On the question of sentence, the High Court observed that the offence of dacoity has increased tremendously. It is a very heinous offence as innocent persons, while sleeping in their houses, are attacked and their belongings are taken by force. The High Court, therefore, was of the opinion that a sentence of five years rigorous imprisonment was extremely inadequate.
for the offence of dacoity under s. 395, Indian Penal Code.
convicted under s. 395, Indian Penal Code, and sentenced to rigorous imprisonment
maximum sentence of imprisonment for life under s. 395, Indian Penal Code.

issues.text: whether the High Court in its revisional jurisdiction, has the power to enhance the sentence, as it has done in the instant case, beyond the limit of the maximum sentence that companyld have been imposed by the trial companyrt, on the accused persons

anchor.surface_text: The only question for determination in this appeal is whether the High Court in its revisional jurisdiction, has the power to enhance the sentence, as it has done in the instant case, beyond the limit of the maximum sentence that companyld have been imposed by the trial

issues.text: whether the High Court had exceeded its powers in enhancing the sentence from 5 to 10 years inasmuch as the trial court itself could not have inflicted a sentence of imprisonment for more than 7 years

anchor.surface_text: contended, in the first place, that the High Court had exceeded its powers in enhancing the sentence from 5 to 10 years inasmuch as the trial court itself could not have inflicted a sentence of imprisonment for more that 7 years.

issues.text: whether the High Court had kept in view the dictum of this Court in the case of Bed Raj v. The State of Uttar Pradesh while enhancing the sentence against the appellants before it

issues.text: Is there anything in the Code of Criminal Procedure, which limits [the High Court's power to enhance the sentence]

anchor.surface_text: Hence, the High Court could impose any sentence up to the maximum limit prescribed by the Indian Penal Code, for a particular offence. In this case, therefore, the High Court could impose the maximum sentence of imprisonment for life under s. 395, Indian Penal Code. Is there anything in the Code of Criminal Procedure, which limits that power ?

anchor.surface_text: The power of the High Court to enhance a sentence, is contained in sub-s. 1 of s. 439 of the Code, which clothes the High Court with the powers of a Court of Appeal under the Code, as also the power to enhance

anchor.surface_text: Thus, the powers of an Assistant Sessions Judge, under s. 31 3 and of a magistrate specially empowered under s. 30 to impose a sentence of imprisonment, are the same, the terms of s. 31 3 and s. 34 being

arguments.claim: No provision in CrPC limits High Court enhancement power as argued; no supporting precedents

anchor.surface_text: The learned counsel for the appellants very properly informed us that there are some reported decisions of some of the High Courts which have gone against his contention, and that there is no decision

arguments.claim: Enhancement is judicial discretion not to be lightly interfered; trial sentence inadequate on facts, rising dacoity requires deterrent

anchor.surface_text: Now, though no limitation has been placed on the High Courts power to enhance it is nevertheless a judicial act and, like all judicial acts involving an exercise of discretion, must be exercised along wellknown

holdings.text: the High Court could impose any sentence up to the maximum limit prescribed by the Indian Penal Code, for a particular offence. In this case, therefore, the High Court could impose the maximum sentence of imprisonment for life under s. 395, Indian Penal Code.

anchor.surface_text: Hence, the High Court could impose any sentence up to the maximum limit prescribed by the Indian Penal Code, for a particular offence. In this case, therefore, the High Court could impose the maximum sentence of imprisonment for life under s. 395, Indian Penal Code. Is there anything in the Code of Criminal Procedure, which limits that power ?

holdings.reasoning_summary: s.439(1) CrPC grants High Court powers of appellate court to enhance sentence without any words of limitation restricting to trial court's maximum.

holdings.text: Sub-section 3 of s. 439, thus, makes it clear that there is no limitation on the power of the High Court to enhance a sentence to the maximum prescribed by the Indian Penal Code, except in cases tried by magistrates other than those especially empowered under s. 30, Criminal Procedure Code.

anchor.surface_text: Sub-section 3 of s. 439, thus, makes it clear that there is nol imitation on the power of the High Court to enhance a sentence to the maximum prescribed by the Indian Penal Code, except in cases tried by magistrates other than those especially empowered under s. 30, Criminal Procedure Code.

holdings.reasoning_summary: s.439(3) CrPC limits enhancement only for sentences passed by Magistrates not empowered under s.30 CrPC; Assistant Sessions Judge under s.31(3) has equivalent powers to s.30 Magistrates, so no limit applies; harmonious reading excludes Sessions cases.

holdings.text: there is no provision in the Code of Criminal Procedure, which limits the power of the High Court in the way suggested on behalf of the appellants, and there are no reasons which militate against the decision of the High Courts taking that view.

anchor.surface_text: The learned counsel for the appellants very properly informed us that there are some reported decisions of some of the High Courts which have-gone against his contention, and that there is no decision which has taken a view in support of his contention. In our opinion, there is no provision in the Code of Criminal Procedure, which limits the power of the High Court in the way suggested on behalf of the appellants,

holdings.reasoning_summary: No statutory provision or precedent supports limiting High Court's enhancement power to trial court's maximum; some High Courts agree.

holdings.text: the question of sentence is a matter of discretion which has to be exercised in a judicial way, that is to say, the sentence imposed by the trial court should not be lightly interfered with and should not be enhanced unless the appellate court comes to the conclusion, on a consideration of the entire circumstances disclosed in the evidence, that the sentence imposed is inadequate.

anchor.surface_text: The case relied upon on behalf of the appellants in support of their second contention Bed Raj v. The State of Uttar Pradesh 1 , also seems to point to the same conclusion as will appear from the following observations at p. 584 Now, though nol imitation has been, placed on the High Courts power to enhance it is nevertheless a judicial act and, like all judicial acts involving an exercise of discretion, must be exercised along wellknown judicial lines. On the second contention,

holdings.reasoning_summary: Following Bed Raj, enhancement requires finding trial sentence inadequate after considering all circumstances; High Court did so properly.

holdings.text: The High Court was, therefore, justified in imposing the sentence of 10 years rigorous imprisonment. In view of the circumstances disclosed in the case, as indicated above, it cannot be asserted that the sentence as enhanced by the High Court is excessive.

anchor.surface_text: In the instant case, the High Court has pointed out that the incidence of the offence of dacoity has gone up to such an extent that in proved cases of serious dacoity, like the one in hand, deterrent punishment is called for. The High Court was, therefore, justified in imposing the sentence of 10 years rigorous imprisonment. In view of the circumstances disclosed in the case, as indicated above, it cannot be asserted that the sentence as enhanced by the High Court is excessive.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Given serious nature of dacoity (armed group, large booty, rising incidence), 5-year sentence inadequate; 10 years deterrent and proportionate.

anchor.surface_text: Hence, the High Court could impose any sentence up to the maximum limit prescribed by the Indian Penal Code, for a particular offence. In this case, therefore, the High Court could impose the maximum sentence of imprisonment for life under s. 395, Indian Penal Code. Is there anything in the Code of Criminal Procedure, which limits that power ?

edges.explanation: The holding in h5 directly addresses the issue in i4 by stating that the High Court was justified in imposing the 10-year rigorous imprisonment sentence and that it cannot be considered too severe in the circumstances

anchor.surface_text: In the instant case, the High Court has pointed out that the incidence of the offence of dacoity has gone up to such an extent that in proved cases of serious dacoity, like the one in hand, deterrent punishment is called for. The High Court was, therefore, justified in imposing the sentence of 10 years rigorous imprisonment. In view of the circumstances disclosed in the case, as indicated above, it cannot be asserted that the sentence as enhanced by the High Court is excessive.
